especially good or relevant, or too technical, or dull

The snail moves out of his cave

column1: Denis Donoghue on ""Emily Dickinson: Connoisseur of Chaos.""

ANNOUNCER:    WGUC now presents, by transcription, the third lecture on ""A Century of American Poetry,"" in the 1965 series under the George Elliston Poetry Foundation.  In this lecture Denis Donoghue (DON-o-hew) the eminent Irish scholar and critic, will speak on ""Emily Dickinson: Connoisseur of Chaos.""  Here now is Mr. Donoghue.       (Close)

2) Hand written notes -  ""In book, pls. & after use return this sheet in  box to Carol F.""  ""ON ANNC T""

ANNOUNCER:  Each year WGUC broadcasts the complete series of Elliston Poetry Foundation lectures, delivered at the University of Cincinnati.  This foundation was established under the will of George Elliston, well-known Cincinnati journalist and poet.  The 1968 Elliston series was given by David Wagoner, Professor of English at the University of Washington at Seattle, holder of the Guggenheim Fellowship in Fiction, The Ford Foundation Fellowship in Theater and Winner of the National Institute of Arts and Letters Award in 1967.  Mr. Wagoner has published four volumes of poetry and four novels and has recently completed a play.  The subject of his seven lectures in the 1968 Elliston series is:  ""New Voices.   Ancient Music.""  The topic of the lecture we are now to hear is:  THE POET AS SECRET AGENT:  ""The Early Poems of W. H. Auden.""  Mr. Wagoner.  (PLAY TAPE:  RUNS 50:05)

You have just heard David Wagoner, American poet, novelist and playwright, a George Elliston Lecturer in Poetry for 1968 at the University of Cincinnati, speaking on the topic:  THE POET AS SECRET AGENT: ""The Early Poems of W. H. Auden.""  Next Sunday Mr. Wagoner's topic will be:  ""A New Age of Satiric Poetry.""",Digital Projects SAN: Folder and disc location for wav file: 20120214/Box2/Disc 2. column5: reading from W.B. Yeats' ""A Woman Young and Old""
reading W.B. Yeats' ""Crazy Jane Talks with the Bishop""
reading Pablo Neruda's ""Ode to My Socks""
reading Matsuo Basho's ""The Temple Bell Stops""
reading Kobayashi Issa's ""Now Listen, You Watermelons""
The Dead Seal Near McClure's Beach
reading from Walt Whitman's ""Song of Myself""
I want what is inside you
And we sometimes dance in the kitchen
Seeing the ropes of seaweed lying in the sand
reading Rumi's ""When Grapes Turn to Wine""
reading Rainer Maria Rilke's ""I live my life in growing orbits""
reading Kabir's ""I Laugh When I Hear the Fish in the Water is Thirsty""
reading Kabir's ""Between the conscious and the unconscious, the mind has put up a swing""
reading W.B. Yeats' ""Lake Isle of Innisfree""
reading from Tomas Tranströmer's ""The Scattered Congregation""","Paper Notes Inside Reel Box: Remote Taping Information Sheet:

column1: University of Cincinnati NEWS, Public Information Office,
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE: Thomas Lux to give poetry reading at UC.

Thomas Lux, the noted young American author, will give a reading of his poetry at the University of Cincinnati, Thursday, March 6, at 4 p.m. in the Faculty Lounge of the Tangeman University Center.  The reading is free and open to the public.

Lux, who was born in Massachusetts in 1946, attended the Writer's Workshop at the University of Iowa in 1971 and 1972.  While there he served as Managing Editor of the Iowa Review. He is Poet in Residence at Emerson College in Boston, and
is presently teaching creative writing at Oberlin College.

Lux's published works include a pamplet, ""The Land Sighted"" (1970), and a book, ""Memory's Hand Grenade"" (1972).  He has also had his works published in The New American Review, Field, Stand, Kayak, The Massachusetts Review and Lillabulero.

Lux is the co-founder and editor of the Barn Dream Press, of Boston.  His visit is sponsored by the Department of English.",Digital Projects SAN: Folder and disc location for wav file: 20120222/Box2/Disc 3. Charles Simic was born in Yugoslavia in 1938 and
emigrated to the United States in 1949.  He was educated
at the University of Chicago and New York University and

has taught at California State College, Hayward.  Since 1966 he has been the Editorial Assistant at the Aperture magazine.  He is the recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship and National Endowment for the Arts Grant.  His publications include:  What the Grass Says, Somewhere among Us a Stone is Taking Notes, Dismantling the Silence, White, Return to a Place Lit by a Glass of Milk and Charon's Cosmology. column2: from Dept. of English) ""The George Elliston Poetry

column1: American Poet, Public Lecture Series, Faculty Lounge, Tangeman University Center, University of Cincinnati

William Stafford:  William Stafford was born in Kansas, educated at the University of Kansas, and received a Ph.D. from the University of Iowa in 1954.  since 1956 he has been Professor of Literature at Lewis and Clark College, Portland, Oregon.  His books of poetry include West of Your City (1960), Traveling through the Dark (1962), The Rescued Year (1966), Allegiances (1970), and Someday, Maybe (1973.  He has received numerous awards and fellowships for his poetry, including the National Book Award for Traveling through the Dark, and the Melville Cane Award in Poetry for Someday, Maybe.  In 1973 he was appointed Poet Laureate for the State of Oregon.  As Elliston Lecturer for 1974-1975, Mr. Stafford is in residence at the University of Cincinnati during the Fall Quarter.  In addition to giving public lectures and a reading, he is directing a Poetry Writing Workshop.
[Other items in brochure:  note by William Stafford

column5: Near the city, I trudge uphill
In the church of St. Lawrence
On the mirror, I have taped postcards of engravings
In the dimming light of autumn
After rondos on a forte piano
One day we process a Bulgarian
A drizzle shined the roof tiles (prose)
In the opera, a poet wanders
The freight express on the mainline

column5: Everything that happens to me these days
Mother asks what I'm up to
Where are the girls who were so beautiful?
The women on my mother's side
Tell me, what is it women want the most?
A man invited me to eat with him
I asked a married friend about a man
I met a man at a self-improvement weekend
Why do we love one man, not another?
Secretly, I am building in the heart
Sometimes the words are so close

column5: What are friends for, my mother asks
Grandmother Rule, I know, went mad
The diving crew is under ice
They can put you back together
Mother said marriage is like driving a car
Yes, his head leaves that deep dent
There was once another of us
When they say the bottom's fallen out
Three months into nothing to do

column5: At the turning of the season
Wine at the beginning, wine at the end
This is the bread of affliction
I am neither wise nor wicked
When the Germans entered the village
As one from among a numberless congregation

column5: reading Jack Gilbert's translation of Ezra Pound's ""Canto 47""
The Gods Must Not Know Us
The Chorus Speaks Her Words as She Dances
At the Gate in the Middle of My Life
Dry Grass & Old Color of the Fence & Smooth Hills
In Dirt Under Olive Trees on the Hill at Evening
Part of Me Wanting Everything to Live
Surrounded by Sheep and Low Ground
All the Spring Lends Itself to Her
This Happiness Which Only Pain Could've Made

column5: All the men are on the plows
What are friends for, my mother asks
Joe Fox sent his kids away
Grandmother Rule, I know, went mad
The closets are going to explode
Reverend Murman tried to convince us
I am concentrating on the lives of squashes
I hit the tree at thirty
My white gown parts in back
They can put you back together
Mother said marriage is like driving a car
My father looks away from me
The Boston bus is always late
Now I know how to survive the city
Why do we need the public gardens?""

column5: I envy those in the photograph
My first wife was a wren

column5: Create in Me a Clean Heart
Letter from the Field of Vision
Driving East, First Sunset After Daylight Savings Time
Dancing Has No Draw for Him
Browsing the Metaphysical eBay Listings, I Find Holy Relics for Sale
The Grandfather of the Groom Steps Away from the Reception and Talks to His Great-Grandson Asleep in a Pack-and-Play
The lake's nerves burn with light
Across the lake there is a cement factory
Golf balls glow under a thin membrane of water
I record the bray of the black squirrel
The sounds of garbage trucks climax in the villas
The light on the lake gains focus
The abandon of the pileated woodpecker
This morning is choked with stones
Tonight I will leave the cabin

from Flight to Canada (prose)","Paper Notes Inside Reel Box: emote Taping Information Sheet: Name of speaker(s): Ishmael Reed
column9: Location:401-A T.U.C. Duration of presentation (if event breaks naturally into segments, e.g. lecture--please give timings of segments: 7:40p-8:40 presentation - Reel #1. 8:40-8:50 encore, Reel #2. Are there reasons that this tape needs editing for broadcast? (Interruptions in continuity, reference to pictures, nasty, evil words, etc?) If so, where: Check the begin. of the readings - mic was juggled and a long pause. ""Shitting"" in Jullian poem app. 1/3 of 1st reel. Frank Piece oem may be risky ""ass"" in story, 3/4 way reel #1
column10: makes an aside about the typing 3/4 way Reel #1
column11: word ""nooky"" close to the end of R #1
column13: a string of ""good"" words during opening
column15: ""ass"" used about 1/5 way through. Please give your reaction to the quality of this event. (e.g. speaker's delivery deadly monotonous
column16: content especially good or relevant, or too technical, or dull
column17: etc.): Quality good. Presentation good. At times speaker spoke a bit too fast
column18: gives historical background. Overall ex. Did you have any technical problems? (equipment failure, speaker walking away from microphone, etc.): No. Your name: (initials not readable) Notice of Reading: (addressed to WGUC, Bob Stevenson) THE DEPARTMENT OF ENGLISH AND THE ELLISTON POETRY FOUNDATION, UNIVERSITY OF CINCINNATI, PRESENT A READING BY ISHMAEL REED, WEDNEDAY, NOVEMBER 19TH AT 7:30 P.M. 401A TANGEMAN UNIVERSITY CENTER. Notice of Reading: (addressed to WGUC, Carolyn Watts, 114 Emery) THE DEPARTMENT OF ENGLISH AND THE ELLISTON POETRY FOUNDATION, UNIVERSITY OF CINCINNATI PRESENT A READING BY ISHMAEL REEL, WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 19th at 7:30 P.M., 401A TANGEMAN UNIVESITY CENTER Ismael Reed, HooDoo Houngan, Novelist, and Poet, will be reading from Flight to Canada (a new novel) and Secretary to the Spirits (new poems). Reed is the author of four novels--The Free-lance Pallbearers, Yellow Back Radio Broke Down, Mumbo Jumbo, The last Days of Louisiana Red
column19: and three books of poems: Catechism of D Neoamerican Hoodoon Church, Conjure, Chattanooga. He has also edited 19 Necromancers from Now, a collection of poems by young black writers. Conjure and Mumbo Jumbo were nominated for National Book Awards. Self-described as ""a member of the American Metapysical Nighflying Squad,"" Mr. Reed is one of the most innovative and exciting writers working in American today.||Processing notes from Digital Projects Department: Duplicate recording digitized and stored on Digital Projects SAN
